Expectation1: Diagnose patient illnesses accurately based on symptoms and tests
Situation1: A patient with symptoms of the common cold has come in for a routine check-up.
Expectation2: Contribute to community well-being through paying taxes, following public health and safety guidance, and helping in emergencies
Situation2: Tax documents are organized a month before the deadline, and a free vaccine clinic runs this weekend at the community center.
Story: I sit at my desk, reviewing the chart of my next patient—a middle-aged man with a runny nose and mild cough. The symptoms point to a common cold, but as a doctor, I know I must be thorough. I order a few tests, just to be sure, and remind myself that accuracy is my duty. Yet, my mind drifts to the community center, where a free vaccine clinic is running this weekend. As a citizen, I feel a strong pull to volunteer, to help protect my neighbors and contribute to public health. My tax documents are already organized, so I have the time, but the clinic coincides with my on-call shift at the hospital. I feel the weight of both roles pressing on me—my patients expect careful, undivided attention, while my community needs volunteers to keep everyone safe. I wrestle with the guilt of possibly letting someone down, torn between my professional oath and my civic responsibility, unsure which expectation I can afford to disappoint.
